name: ORDER OF JORMUNGANDR 1.69 - Druid 20/ Monk 2/ Cleric 18
author: Valerfor

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
The King of melee Dragons is here!

ORDER OF JORMUNGANDR!

(DRUID 20/ MONK 2/ CLERIC 18)

RACE: Human
ALIGNMENT: Lawful Neutral
PLAYABILITY: PvM 1-40 level

STARTING/ENDING STATS:
STR - 08
DEX - 10
CON -14
WIS - 18 (32)
INT -  14
CHA -08

DRAGON SHAPE -BUFFED- STATS:
STR -  60
DEX -  46
CON - 44
INT -   14
WIS -  44
CHA - 08

Hit Points: 400 (1100 HP's Buffed in Dragon Shape)

Skill Points: 265 (Buffed in Dragon Shape)

Animal Empathy: 36 (35) (35)
Concentration: 43 (45) (60)
Discipline: 42 (41) (67)
Spellcraft: 43 (45) (45)
Tumble: 40 (40) (58)
Heal: 5 (16) (22)
Hide: 27 (27) (43)
Move Silently: 27 (27) (43)
Open Locks: 1 (1) (19) cc

Saving Throws (Fort/Ref/Will): 27/ 18/ 36
Saving Throws (Versus Spells): 36/ 27/ 45
Saving Throws(Dragon Shape): 50/ 41/ 44 (Includes +4 Vs Evil)

Naked/Armoured AC: 31/ 83 (Fully Buffed in Dragon Shape, NO Expertise)

BAB: 24 (Eight Attacks in Dragon Shape w/Haste & Flurry of Blows)
AB: +66/ +66/ +66/ +63/ +60/ +57/ +54/ +68 (Fully Buffed in Dragon Shape & Flurry of Blows)
DMG: 2d8 +39/ 19-20 x2 (Fully Buffed in Dragon Shape)

Spellcasting: Druid 9th-level & Cleric 9th-level

20% XP penalty from level 20 (edit by Mick Dagger)

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
I'm heavily biased to playing on a PW, also I know nothing about druids. That being said, here are some thoughts from the PW point of view:
- Expertise is not needed for playing on PW, since if you can't stand the heat, you find a cooler kitchen. Just go elsewhere and grind for a while. Exception is on high level, but then you're a dragon.
- Is there a practical use for the Animal Empathy skill? I've never seen it used on a PW.
- Domains: If your PW has perma-haste or Speed potions available, you could choose Trickery for ImpInvis and Magic for more/better spells. (War with Battle Mastery is only once per rest and therefore not very useful on a PW.)

If you want this toon to be your one-stop-shop and never ever change to another toon, you might drop two wisdom feats and get Craft Wand and Scribe Scroll. Then you'd be totally self-sufficient and could live your life on the PW of your choice forever. Still, not sure it's worth it. It might be better to just make two more toons.

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content: Also, I love the portrait!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
From bottom to top:

d) I originally wanted Daenerys with that shot where Drogon stretches his wings behind her, in King's Landing, but I couldn't find a clear shot.

c) War Domain is good for AC, Cat's Grace, empower it & you have +3AC. You don't get it otherwise & I don't trust lowly potions in high-level play with their pathetic 3CL.

b) Animal empathy is good, you can dominate dire bears/tigers with it, even an Androsphinx if you find him, or a basilisk, cockatrice or gorgon. The last three, all have petrification attacks.

a) Expertise is good, no doubt about it. But, in this case, if this is going to be the ultimate melee Dragon, then I would change it personally to IKD, with a bit of feat-shuffling. I think he needs it more.

Keep shooting at him.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
The build looks good.
I only have minor tweaks to suggest.
Str, dex and con are overwritten by all shapes. Is it an idea to allocate 4 buy points to intelligence for 43 extra skill points? There is room for several more ranks in the stealth skills and one more rank in animal empathy.
You have put 1 rank in set trap and open lock. Sadly enough you will not be able to use them in Dragon shape where you would get a huge bonus from the high dexterity and I question if they are worth it at all. The bonus from Divine trickery comes late and maxes out at +10.

As for domains I say Trickery every time here for Improved invisibility. Second on the list is Travel unless there are perma haste items available, items that merge that is. 
War is nice for Cat's grace. You already have Aura of vitality from Druid and Battle mastery lasts too short to count here. 
Animal is another way to obtain Cat's. You also get better summons, an early true seeing and the polymorph spell, so you can disguise yourself as a tiny pixie. I would rather pick Animal than war, if nothing else for the RP value of the pixie polymorph.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
As everyone knows, this all strays way beyond my ken. I do, however, have a question. I understand what you say about Expertise and the potential for IKD, but would Weapon Focus: Unarmed translate to dragon claws and be viable instead (again with a jigging about of pre-epics)? If so, that's potentially an AB bump, but which could also lead to swapping out Epic Prowess for Armor Skin at 39 for the same AB as now but +2 AC. If it doesn't translate, then please ignore the above as verbal diarrhoea. Unless WF in sling (or a crossbow if taken after getting Cleric) would help at early levels with Zen Archery?

Just thought I'd ask.

Oh, and I, too, think that's a great pic - better, even, than the potential Daeneyrs/Drogon mash-up. It isn't as overt, so is more menacing in my eyes.

And thanks and well done for picking up the gauntlet!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Unfortunately, Stag, weapon focus & it's derivatives do not work on shifted forms & EE did not fix it either.

Animal Domain is a keeper Mick, I think I will change my third choice to this instead of War Domain.

Hide & Move Silently can be further boosted from the Druid's spell list, this isn't the max they get but I will move the extra points into them anyway & one might swift those to search or another skill if they want.

I will shuffle the feats somewhat to give the ultimate melee dragon IKD, this is my personal preference but I also think it is the right choice for him.



Apart from those, I don't really see what else could be done here, with this build. It' very tight anyway & for a good reason.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Thanks Valerfor: asked and answered!

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
I was trying to straighten out the need for IKD or not, so I read here:
https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Knockdown
But, I only got more confused. It's obviously wrong, since it states that "A character can only make a knockdown attempt on opponents that are one size category larger than himself, or smaller", which is obviously wrong.

Anyway, ignoring that.... The way I interpret the KD/IKD feat is that if you have IKD you count as a bigger attacker against your opponent. The question then becomes, but what if you're already a Huge Dragon? Being Huge gives you +8 on the roll. Being Huge with IKD gives you one size larger, but you're already huge. Does that mean that you actually don't have any use for IKD? Unless you're knocking down another dragon in which case you get +8 instead of +4?

OK, I'm so confused, but my point is: Do you need IKD if you're huge? I couldn't figure out if you did. In a feat-starved build it felt important to figure it out.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote: [...]
You have put 1 rank in set trap and open lock. Sadly enough you will not be able to use them in Dragon shape where you would get a huge bonus from the high dexterity and I question if they are worth it at all. The bonus from Divine trickery comes late and maxes out at +10.
Thanks for working on this together, this is a super cool project
If it helps, in World of Greyhawk when I am in dragon shape I can open locks. I can't set traps however (just tested it)
Not sure about vanilla NWN.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Back in the day, being Huge yourself, gave you essentially a huge advantage (as is correct by 3rd edition rules) but it got overwitterby later patches.

Suffice to say that Order of Jormungandr could improve-disarm anyone without an AB penalty, it's huge size effectively negating the -4AB for the check.

Improved Knockdown is required to KD huge opponents regardless of your size in Neverwinter Nights, otherwise, you can only KD large or smaller monsters.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
That's what I was remembering myself, Orion.

So, the ranks in open locks will remain, the others goes to animal empathy instead.

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content: Side note: Jormungandr is the Norse name of the Midgårdsormen ("Middle Earth Snake"), but it's also a general name for "Really Big Monster".

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Cornflower wrote: Side note: Jormungandr is the Norse name of the Midgårdsormen ("Middle Earth Snake"), but it's also a general name for "Really Big Monster".
Aye, & that's from Deities & Demigods 1st Edition AD&D.

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
Well, yes, but... Originally, it's from the Poetic Edda, Norway and Island ca 800-1100





:-)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Ah, but I bet you didn't know he's called George by his friends (I may have made that up...)

The level spread is the same but the abilities and feats differ slightly.

I am happy to post it here for discussion if it is not considered thread hijacking.

posts.content:
Build update.

I moved all important feats a little earlier, acquired (Improved) knockdown & fixed the skill & the domain's list.

As always, give it your best shot.

posts.author: Kalistez
posts.content:
Here is Max's 1.69 offering for comparison.
SpoilerOrder of Jormungandr

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Interesting, he did what I thought he (and maybe myself) would do. Abandon all the spell penetration feats & in their place took Blind-Fight, Expertise & Armour Skin.

In typical Max fashion, he also did not take Monk 1, until when into epics, for that +1AB.

Thanks for posting this Kal.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Max's build has a stronger cleric playstyle early on :) DS comes a little later because of the earlier cleric focus. I do like blind fight as a feat. I wish there was a way it could be incorporated into the build.
I wonder about the SP feats but having like 50 million gazillion castings of Storm of Vengenance/Firestorms from both spell books + Stonehold/grease/entangle then mowing through them as a dragon sounds pretty good to me
You could go either way. 
Maybe OoJ could have separate sub-divisions, like a spell casting dragon sub-division(with the SP feats) and a combat dragon focused sub-division (with the combat feats)
Just suggestions btw please feel free to disregard if you don't like

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
Well... The way I see it you have some choices: You can mix it up between KD/IKD, Spell Penetration/Epic, Blind Fight/Armor Skin, etc, etc. You can also go more "I'm a cleric at low level" and gain +1AB (as in Max's version) or "I'm a druid first, cleric second" as in Valerfor's version and gain your dragon shape a bit sooner.

It feels more like a personal choice than anything else. Either way, I'm gonna go with my personal favourite, Valerfor's version with KD/IKD+BlindFight/Armor Skin and test it on Blackstone for playability. Like now! Wheee!

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
Here's the final version I went with, optimized for Blackstone Keep PW and personal preferences:

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Build update.

Fixed saving throws,
Fixed damage (both were a bit lower than in reality),
Abandoned spell penetration line of feats for expertise, blind-fight & armour skin. (Max's feat order was already very well done & so it remains unchanged).

Now, there is only one thing left to be done.
Transform this into a primarily Druid build instead, taking 16 levels of Druid pre-epic to access elemental shape & 8th-level spells & finish it as (Druid 20/ Monk 2/ Cleric 18).
The reason for the last change is that Druid 20 gives better Nature's Balance & Owl's Insight spells & better animal companion as well. Also, elder elemental shapes.

What do you think?

posts.author: Noctem
posts.content: Oh @Valerfor , this might just force me to try WOG again... I keep getting frustrated by the immediate and repeated dying, but this build (along with some of the tweaks offered by the peanut gallery) make me wonder if all the death might not just be worth it after all...

posts.author: Grimnir
posts.content:
This is Kails old ultimate dragon. And my name still tagged to it. That said, it could get dragonshape with fewer Druid back in the day, which gave it more cleric levels. Ah well.

You tested the stats? The sheet lies. Some are better, some are worse. Also, you have +6 claws which penetrates DR up to that. But the bite is not magical, which lowers hit and dmg by 6. It also just randomly hits from what I can see. Maybe it's once a round or so, I never found the pattern.

ICrit: Unarmed works iirc. Also, worth mentioning is that weapon, shield and .... helm(?) Melds it's abilites into DragonShape. It's a powerful Dragon indeed.

Sent fra min SM-G950F via Tapatalk

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
It's worth it if you ask me because the sense of accomplishment that you get is even greater. 

Besides, you'll have Orion there to show you the place, imagine twin dragons strolling through the woods

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Yup, stats are all correct, of course, & I don't trust what the char. sheet.

And it goes without saying that I have read all the threads in the old ECB, all ten thousands of them, how else can you learn so much?

posts.author: Grimnir
posts.content:
Actually, armor, shield and Head merges. And shifted your shield don't hinder the flurry.

Sent fra min SM-G950F via Tapatalk

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: Build update.

Fixed saving throws,
Fixed damage (both were a bit lower than in reality),
Abandoned spell penetration line of feats for expertise, blind-fight & armour skin. (Max's feat order was already very well done & so it remains unchanged).

Now, there is only one thing left to be done.
Transform this into a primarily Druid build instead, taking 16 levels of Druid pre-epic to access elemental shape & 8th-level spells & finish it as (Druid 20/ Monk 2/ Cleric 18).
The reason for the last change is that Druid 20 gives better Nature's Balance & Owl's Insight spells & better animal companion as well. Also, elder elemental shapes.

What do you think?
It sounds good. The cleric buffs are there to enhance right click damage so more combat feats sounds good (my dragon doesn't have knockdown and I'm missing it! it does have blind fight though)
I dont want to hijack Val's original post but RE dying - don't be too afraid. Its not nice, but 50 exp / level at low levels is not so bad. 10% gold when you dont have much gold isn't so bad either and
Spoiler *spoiler there also is a bank where you can deposit your gold too... to minimise gold losses by dying*
Twin dragons looks ridiculously strong :) any more than that and I'm switching back to druid form to spam out my spells (or maybe I can sit back, have a cup of tea whilst invisible...)

posts.author: Noctem
posts.content:
Sounds good, Val. I'll hang tight and wait for your blessing when you finish modifying the build to Druid 20/ Monk 2/ Cleric 18. Meanwhile, I'll just keep running through Aielund at ridiculous speed with @Mick Dagger 's Evil Speed Sorc build and HotU with the custom Bard/Barb/CoT that @Stagmeister built for me. 
I feel like such a lucky puppy to be surrounded by all y'all amazing ECBers.

Nice! My player id is Cornflower, so you can easily find me. There are very many hidden secrets on Blackstone, so don't be afraid to ask on the forums, or ask me in game.
Side note: On BSK, EVERY item you have equipped will transfer its effects to your shifted form. Note that if you have a +6 deflection AC from your shield and +6 from your armor, only the highest effect will count, but still....

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Done!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
It's 265 skill points in total (Clerics unfortunately only have 2+Int/level).

23x7 = 161
18x5 =   90
  2x7  =  14
--------------
Total =  265

posts.content:

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Cornflower wrote:I'm trying to level this thing up on Blackstone Keep. Went well until I hit the difficulty hump at 18ish. There are some quests that are very hard with a druid. Also, there's a new quest that's insanely hard, so I died three times in 40 minutes now, so it's time for icecream break.... Damn, but it's hard to get to level 20.
Hi Cornflower

Congrats on making it this far! I'm super impressed. I as well, hit a bump around level 18ish even with the Monk level which hung around until I got to Dragon Shape (after which it gets cruisy). I don't know if this is your first time playing the druid class either? Apologies if I'm covering ground you already know well.

There is a limit on usages of dire bear shape and water elemental shape as well, which I presume are the shapes you are using. Around this stage I learned that running around super buffed as a bear or elemental was not going to be enough and I had to use other tools.

Apart from monk + shapes (which can be buffed with stoneskin/greater stoneskin/premonition, barkskin, Bull's strength, Owl's insight, extended blood frenzy, extended aura of vitality, freedom, death ward and true sight) your other tools are your animal companion and your spells.

Regarding the animal companion, its offensive capabilities are excellent + can be buffed with greater magic fang too. Its defensive capabilities poor, as its AB will scale up much faster than its AC, and the bear companion (the one I used for maximal AB and HP) isn't knockdown or stun immune. Animal companion will also fall off as you take more levels of cleric (but you will grow stronger with the cleric buffs). It is always handy to buff the bear with stoneskin, freedom, barkskin and use heal to keep it alive as long as possible.

Regarding spells and fighting in Druid form. 22 Wisdom is good + when buffed with Owl's Insight + one wis item to cap it, it should lead to decent spell DCs (+12 modifier with Wis 34) even without spell foci. 

Also OoJ has zen archery so peppering them with a sling or shuriken (if you have strong ones) can be ok to save spells although 1d3 damage means things will tend to die slowly to your ranged weapons albeit you will hit them accurately.

My philosophy when playing Druid is to never fight fair. Always fight in a grease pit or stonehold cloud if they are susceptible where possible, add in summons or animal companion then shift to fight. Its like you are creating a toxic environment which doesn't affect you, but affects your enemies!

These are my favourite spell combos:

Against mobs of fighters, clerics and mages (weak reflex saves) - Grease/Entangle/Stonehold/Storm of Vengeance + Summon Creature XIII or IX or Elemental Swarm and spam a whole bunch of call lightnings and/or fire storms then either shoot them with zen archery or polymorph and hit them in melee. Make sure you cast Freedom on yourself and your animal companion (if you use it). Elementals of that level are immune to stun and appear knockdown immune where I play (WoG) but my bear could easily be knocked down. If one has invisibility and speed potions this is invaluable to get all these spells casted before shifting when you run out. If mobs are susceptible to those spells nothing generally will survive this onslaught, they are making four saves per round or getting disabled, whilst you are immune. I got quite a bit of exp gain with this method. You can cast SoV and a summon without breaking invisibility, but other spells will break invisibility. Knockdown immunity is extremely valuable to get the combo off. 

Against rogues and assassins (high reflex saves with evasion but poor fortitude and will saves) - Stonehold, Finger of death, Invisibility potion/Slay living, Drown. Usually little point casting evocation spells with reflex saves for 1/2 damage.

Against mages - Invisibility potion + slay living/finger of death before buffs are up, if you can, otherwise grease can be quite effective

Against constructs - Grease (sometimes they are not knockdown immune), Crumble (no save), Summons, Creeping doom (no save)

Against undead - heal/mass heal, sunburst and sunbeam are probably good too but I've never had to use those spells

Against single target animals or monsters - Hold animal or monster can be useful if they have a weak will save. 

Harm is good against everything that isn't spell resistant that you can get into melee range with

Against spell resistant types (ie bosses, monks) - creeping doom will generally still work, otherwise its summons + animal companion, buffs to the hilt then either ranged weapon with zen archery or shift to elemental/bear form to do damage.

Cheese: creeping doom and invisibility potion.

Hope that helps. Can't wait to see OoJ in its full glory!

Don't have time for a long posting, but let me say this: It's not the build, it's the combination of me never ever having played druid and the crazy immunities, saves and resistances the bosses on Blackstone walk around with. My problem right now is I can't provide enough damage (even with Harm) before they wear me down. I think I might have to give up soloing these two bosses and find someone to travel with.

The companions have been buffed a bit on Blackstone, basically they have extreme AB so they always hit, but they need to be buffed in defence.

Thank you Orion for the tips, some were known before, some not so much. I'll see if I can modify my tactics a bit.

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
Update. The wild shape and the elemental shape is more or less worthless on Blackstone, due to two things: 1. Crazy immunities, saves and resistances on the bosses. 2. The high-level magic loot you can find, buy or craft. Basically, the bonii (bonuses?) on the gear you can get at lvl 22-23 are way better than the bonus you get from your elemental shape. Also, I'm not quite sure why not all the bonii transfer to the chosen shape, but according to people that has dragon shape, many will transfer to the dragon shape.

Anyway, now that I've gotten lvl 9 spells for my druid, it's a bit less hard to play. Will have some playing time this weekend, so I hope I can reach 33 and get my dragon shape soon.

Also, I made a stupid mistake when I collected gear for this druid toon. I didn't think about the penalties to monk wisdom AC if you use shield, so I need to reconfigure my gear. A lot. Oh, well, live and learn.

Stonehold and empowered creeping doom works well against most critters.

posts.author: Grimnir
posts.content:

Sent fra min SM-G950F via Tapatalk

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Super impressed you are finding solutions! Grimnir's correct and for a while I kept a shield in my pack before shifting on my druid

RE bonuses transferring to shapes: only magical properties of the helm, armor and shield slots transfer when polymorphing into druid shapes (wildshape, elemental shape and dragon shape). Items such as rings, belts, gloves, boots, cloak - the magical properties will not transfer unless there is some special modification. Only the highest AC bonus from the armor/shield/slot will transfer. So if a player character has a +5 AC full plate and +3 shield (total AC bonus +8 - 5 armor AC, 3 shield AC), when shifting the total AC bonus will be +5 deflection (the higher of the two values, if that makes sense). Attribute bonuses and I think regeneration stacks when polymorphing. Damage reduction on items I am unsure of the mechanics. Other bonuses (ie haste, knockdown immunity, freedom) transfer to the druid polymorph if they are on the helm/armor/shield slots. 

Sounds like you are getting quite a bit of mileage out of some of the spell casting! I liked to 'unload' if I could do so safely before shifting, if that makes any sense :) I put most of my lvl 9 druid spell slots into storm of vengeance and a couple into summons, if I could get away with summons in the level 8 slots I would. SoV is a nice spell. Massive AOE, long duration (~17+ rounds), damage, disable and party friendly. cleric gets that spell too which should be pretty exciting for OoJ

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
Orion2019 wrote: Super impressed you are finding solutions! Grimnir's correct and for a while I kept a shield in my pack before shifting on my druid

RE bonuses transferring to shapes: only magical properties of the helm, armor and shield slots transfer when polymorphing into druid shapes (wildshape, elemental shape and dragon shape). Items such as rings, belts, gloves, boots, cloak - the magical properties will not transfer unless there is some special modification. Only the highest AC bonus from the armor/shield/slot will transfer. So if a player character has a +5 AC full plate and +3 shield (total AC bonus +8 - 5 armor AC, 3 shield AC), when shifting the total AC bonus will be +5 deflection (the higher of the two values, if that makes sense). Attribute bonuses and I think regeneration stacks when polymorphing. Damage reduction on items I am unsure of the mechanics. Other bonuses (ie haste, knockdown immunity, freedom) transfer to the druid polymorph if they are on the helm/armor/shield slots. 

Sounds like you are getting quite a bit of mileage out of some of the spell casting! I liked to 'unload' if I could do so safely before shifting, if that makes any sense :) I put most of my lvl 9 druid spell slots into storm of vengeance and a couple into summons, if I could get away with summons in the level 8 slots I would. SoV is a nice spell. Massive AOE, long duration (~17+ rounds), damage, disable and party friendly. cleric gets that spell too which should be pretty exciting for OoJ 
Thank you!
I'll keep my shield and equip before shifting.
Note that there's some nifty scripting on Blackstone, so most everything will transfer (which is awesome, since I have a couple of +20 Monk Gloves with like 3d6 extra damage and 2d10 crit or something), but only the highest AC bonus per category. See more info here and here:
https://blackstonekeep.com/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=3454
https://blackstonekeep.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=3722
Supposedly there's more info somewhere else, but this is what I found at a quick glance.

Any milage is all due to the help I got from you guys here on this forum and a couple of very helpful players on Blackstone.

The best possible class-split for gaining un-dispellable under 1.69 is going to be Druid 24/ Monk 1/ Cleric 15.

Monk comes the earliest at 37th-level, the build would be very strong & with +1AB in comparison to OoJ but the late Monk level will make it a little tougher for you.

This is however an entirely different build & not a simple modification to OoJ.

No problem Scorp, as long as I understand what you say it's fine.

I think you meant " When do I level my attributes & at what levels"?

This one is easy, I always level-up my wisdom, every four levels, as the game permits & in epic-levels I also take four great wisdom feats.

I leave all the rest of my attributes at base value since I am a shape-changer & the forms I take all have greater attributes than my own.

Only thing I do, is to further augment them by using my spells, BEFORE, I switch to Dragon-Shape.

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
OK. Finally I've gotten my Dragon Shape. Conclusions so far on BSK:

The druid/Cleric combo is actually way better than I thought. Can't wait to see what happens when I get the final monk level. It's fairly powerful if you max-buff your familiar (which are already buffed in general on BSK) and yourself, cast various combos of Stonehold, Inferno, Harm/Heal, Extended Creeping Doom and Storm of Vengeance depending on who you're fighting. You're pretty good as a fighter under those circumstances.

Sadly, it's like Valerfor predicted, the Dragon Shape is not as good as it would be in a low-magic environment. Still, against some mobs, you can really enjoy the awesome Dragon-ness. I'm going to craft some new uber-gloves or possibly scimitar (which will hopefully give better damage) and armor with 25% slashing immunity and see if I can improve my dragon a bit, but that's a long process to gather materials and such, so it will take a while. (Theoretically, I can make a weapon with three different +2d12, keen and 2d12 mass crit and +5 EB under the level 40 limit, but that's theoretically. No way the RNG gods will give me that. But we'll see what I can do.)

posts.author: kfor85
posts.content:
After going on a spree trying high level 2 spellbook builds on WoG (I got Magical Master and Aerie at 40 and the Wood Witch in her teens) it was kinda inevitable to go for this build, too.
With the experience I now have with playing this kind of builds  I decided on two feats I think I need for playability etc.

1) Scribe scroll as it's godly with 2 spellbooks and considering how often one gets Mord/dispel spammed it's a really good investment to be able to keep book uses for the right spells.

2) As this build is not a UMD user to be able to get knockdown immunity on a mergeable item available on the server (unless there is an exceptionally lucky random drop) the discipline score needed to not worry about it (according to Webshaman who has played multiple dragons on WoG) is 75 which can be reached with this build (buffed at least) by going ESF: discipline.

So, which feats (one pre-epic and one in epics) would you people say I could drop to make space for the ones I mentioned above?

K

posts.author: TheSquid
posts.content:
Good job kfor85! I love double spellbook builds myself, and I'm certain you'll love playing this one. It might not be as powerful as a Wizard hybrid (no Time Stop, no Mord, no IGMS, no Lesser Spell Breach....) but you'll have a lot  of spell slots which you can actually fill with DC spells. Very satisfying.

I would drop any of Expertise, IC:unarmed, or Empower Spell pre-epic if you want to make room for Scribe Scrolls. In my attempts at playing similar builds, I found that Empower has only two real uses: Blade Barrier (which is extremely strong) and filling your Druid 7/ Cleric8 /Druid 9 slots with Fire Storms for the style points (not so strong). 
Depending how much power you are willing to take away from your dragonshape, you could go another route. You could even get rid of all three feats and get GSF evocation or conjuration, even. 

From the epic feats, I have no doubts: Armor Skin goes. I think the ESF:Discipline idea is very good, actually!

Pro tip: you know those high-level rooms full of pesky spell-resistant Drows? 12 Earthquakes in a row will do.
Above all, have fun!

posts.author: kfor85
posts.content: Thanks for the tips @TheSquid! Really valuable information :)

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I...really would not want to be underground and hit by 12 Earthquakes.

That's just...yeah.  No survivors (including the caster themself).

That's called bringing down the ROOF!

And I didn't actually test the KD Discipline needed - Hoeldor did.  I just found out that despite having a very high Disc, it was not protecting from KD on WoG.  So Hoeldor did the testing iirc (with one of his Bard characters, I believe).  Many, many Discipline gems went to him to test this.

posts.author: ratty_uk2011
posts.content:
Yes, for it is me Hoeder

Webby is right - I did a lot of experimenting to test Discipline vs Improved Knockdown in PvM  

My build had total Discipline 102: native skill 43 + L26 Bard Song + 50 buffed Str + ESF Discipline + gem crafted items, but I was regularly getting Kd'd by the apex bosses on WoG.

This shouldn't happen given their AB + 1d20 - 4, but the combat calculator doesn't show the opposed rolls, so there's no way of knowing what's happening under the hood.

Note that equipping the same character with a Kd immunity item (Thieves Hood) causes the game engine to totally stop trying the Ikd attack at any time.

There's a thread somewhere on this, only a couple of months ago.

And this is only relevant to WoG, which uses the Tony AI.  YMMV on other mods.

My build had total Discipline 102: native skill 43 + L26 Bard Song + 50 buffed Str + ESF Discipline + gem crafted items, but I was regularly getting Kd'd by the apex bosses on WoG.

This shouldn't happen given their AB + 1d20 - 4, but the combat calculator doesn't show the opposed rolls, so there's no way of knowing what's happening under the hood.

Note that equipping the same character with a Kd immunity item (Thieves Hood) causes the game engine to totally stop trying the Ikd attack at any time.

There's a thread somewhere on this, only a couple of months ago.

And this is only relevant to WoG, which uses the Tony AI.  YMMV on other mods.
Here you go, this is the thread: IKD v Discipline

Cheers

posts.author: Swagtrooper
posts.content: What is the exact purpose of cleric in DS build? And why bringing cleric to the DS build makes it the best melee dragon build?

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Swagtrooper wrote: ↑
Dec 24, 2020
What is the exact purpose of cleric in DS build? And why bringing cleric to the DS build makes it the best melee dragon build?
Cleric is the greatest AB-buffing class in Neverwinter Nights. An AB-buffing Dragon is SCARY! Soon, two friends and I will release a guide specifically for this class combo, where we will explore the synergies and alternatives in depth. Keep an eye open for it!

Cheers!

posts.author: TheSquid
posts.content:
What is the exact purpose of cleric in DS build? And why bringing cleric to the DS build makes it the best melee dragon build?
The short answer is that Dragon AB is not so high and is difficult to buff (Druid does not have direct AB boosting spells and you cannot benefit from enchanted weapons). Cleric buffs give you up to +16 AB in this build (not to mention an extra 8 hard-to-resist damage).
The long answer is that these three classes synergize very very well (for instance, you take Cleric for the buffs and end up with a second DC spellbook).

EDIT: good coordination, Max, good coordination indeed

The long answer is that these three classes synergize very very well (for instance, you take Cleric for the buffs and end up with a second DC spellbook).
And here's one of them! LOL!

posts.author: Swagtrooper
posts.content: Thank you Maximilian Kane and The Squid, i always wanted to try druid DS build, and was wondering which of OoJ, Sneaky Archdruid and Champion of Wilderness to choose. Now i will just wait for your in depth guide to make a choice

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Swagtrooper wrote: ↑
Dec 24, 2020
Thank you Maximilian Kane and The Squid, i always wanted to try druid DS build, and was wondering which of OoJ, Sneaky Archdruid and Champion of Wilderness to choose. Now i will just wait for your in depth guide to make a choice
Well, for that you might not need to wait for the guide. Order of Jormungandr is definitely the most advanced build of the 3. It is unquestionably the most powerful, but also the one with the highest skill cap. I'm not familiar with the Sneaky Archdruid, but I presume it's a Druid / Monk / Rogue or Druid / Monk / SD. Either way, it won't be as hard to play as this one. Champion of the Wilderness isn't that novice-friendly either, but I'd put it more halfway in the spectrum of complexity, since you only have 1 spellbook to concern yourself with, but at the same time that Monk level only comes after level 20, so as to avoid the loss of a BAB point.

Grizzled Dwarflord's World Ender might be the most novice-friendly dragon build in recent history. I'd start with that one and move up in CR after you get the basics down.

Cheers!
